items.title: I can identify the location, charge, and relative mass of protons, neutrons, and electrons
items.what: Atoms contain three subatomic particles. Protons (positive, mass 1) and neutrons (neutral, mass 1) are in the nucleus. Electrons (negative, negligible mass) orbit in shells around the nucleus.
items.why: Knowing particle properties helps you understand why atoms are electrically neutral and how ions form when electrons are gained or lost.
items.example: A carbon atom has 6 protons (+6 charge) and 6 electrons (-6 charge) in the nucleus, giving it no overall charge. The 6 neutrons add mass but no charge.

subtopic.name: Atomic Structure
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the fundamental building blocks of atoms: protons, neutrons, and electrons. You will learn where each particle is located, its charge and mass, and how to use atomic number and mass number to determine the composition of any atom.
subtopic.why: Understanding atomic structure is essential because it explains why elements behave differently. The number of protons defines which element you have, and this knowledge forms the foundation for understanding the entire periodic table.

items.title: I can use atomic number to determine the number of protons and electrons in a neutral atom
items.what: The atomic number (Z) equals the number of protons in an atom. In a neutral atom, the number of electrons equals the number of protons.
items.why: Atomic number is how we identify elements. Every calcium atom has exactly 20 protons, which is why calcium's atomic number is 20.
items.example: Calcium has atomic number 20, so a neutral calcium atom has 20 protons in its nucleus and 20 electrons orbiting around it.

subtopic.name: Atomic Structure
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the fundamental building blocks of atoms: protons, neutrons, and electrons. You will learn where each particle is located, its charge and mass, and how to use atomic number and mass number to determine the composition of any atom.
subtopic.why: Understanding atomic structure is essential because it explains why elements behave differently. The number of protons defines which element you have, and this knowledge forms the foundation for understanding the entire periodic table.

items.title: I can calculate the number of neutrons using mass number and atomic number
items.what: Mass number (A) equals protons plus neutrons. To find neutrons, subtract atomic number from mass number: neutrons = A - Z.
items.why: Different isotopes of the same element have different numbers of neutrons, which affects physical properties like density and radioactivity.
items.example: Sodium-23 has mass number 23 and atomic number 11. Neutrons = 23 - 11 = 12 neutrons.

subtopic.why: Understanding atomic structure is essential because it explains why elements behave differently. The number of protons defines which element you have, and this knowledge forms the foundation for understanding the entire periodic table.

items.title: I can interpret nuclide notation to determine subatomic particle numbers
items.what: Nuclide notation shows an element's symbol with mass number (top) and atomic number (bottom). From this you can calculate protons, neutrons, and electrons.
items.why: This notation is used throughout chemistry to precisely identify specific isotopes of elements.
items.example: For ³¹₁₅P (phosphorus-31): atomic number 15 means 15 protons and 15 electrons; mass number 31 means 31 - 15 = 16 neutrons.

subtopic.why: Understanding atomic structure is essential because it explains why elements behave differently. The number of protons defines which element you have, and this knowledge forms the foundation for understanding the entire periodic table.

items.title: I can explain what isotopes are and how they differ from each other
items.what: Isotopes are atoms of the same element with the same number of protons but different numbers of neutrons. They have identical chemical properties but different masses.
items.why: Isotopes explain why atomic masses on the periodic table are not whole numbers, and why some atoms are radioactive while others are stable.
items.example: Carbon-12 and carbon-14 are both carbon (6 protons each), but carbon-12 has 6 neutrons while carbon-14 has 8 neutrons, making it heavier and radioactive.

subtopic.name: Atomic Structure
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the fundamental building blocks of atoms: protons, neutrons, and electrons. You will learn where each particle is located, its charge and mass, and how to use atomic number and mass number to determine the composition of any atom.
subtopic.why: Understanding atomic structure is essential because it explains why elements behave differently. The number of protons defines which element you have, and this knowledge forms the foundation for understanding the entire periodic table.

items.title: I can state the maximum number of electrons that can occupy each shell
items.what: The first shell holds up to 2 electrons. The second and third shells hold up to 8 electrons each. Electrons fill from the innermost shell outward.
items.why: Understanding shell capacity explains why elements in the same group have similar properties and why noble gases are stable.
items.example: Argon has 18 electrons arranged as 2 in the first shell, 8 in the second shell, and 8 in the third shell (2,8,8).

subtopic.name: Electron Configuration
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how electrons are arranged in shells around the nucleus. You will learn the rules for filling electron shells and how to represent electron arrangements using shell diagrams and electron configuration notation.
subtopic.why: Electron configuration determines an element's chemical behaviour. Elements react to achieve stable, full outer shells, so knowing how electrons are arranged lets you predict how elements will bond and react.

items.title: I can draw electron shell diagrams for elements 1-20
items.what: Shell diagrams show concentric circles around a nucleus, with dots or crosses representing electrons in each shell. Electrons fill inner shells first before moving to outer shells.
items.why: Shell diagrams provide a visual way to understand electron arrangement and predict chemical bonding behaviour.
items.example: A magnesium atom (12 electrons) is drawn with a nucleus containing 12 protons, with 2 electrons in the first ring, 8 in the second ring, and 2 in the third ring.

subtopic.name: Electron Configuration
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how electrons are arranged in shells around the nucleus. You will learn the rules for filling electron shells and how to represent electron arrangements using shell diagrams and electron configuration notation.
subtopic.why: Electron configuration determines an element's chemical behaviour. Elements react to achieve stable, full outer shells, so knowing how electrons are arranged lets you predict how elements will bond and react.

items.title: I can write electron configurations using comma notation
items.what: Electron configuration notation lists the number of electrons in each shell, separated by commas. For example, chlorine with 17 electrons has the configuration 2,8,7.
items.why: This notation provides a quick way to communicate electron arrangement without drawing diagrams.
items.example: Potassium has 19 electrons. Its electron configuration is 2,8,8,1 showing electrons distributed across four shells.

subtopic.name: Electron Configuration
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how electrons are arranged in shells around the nucleus. You will learn the rules for filling electron shells and how to represent electron arrangements using shell diagrams and electron configuration notation.
subtopic.why: Electron configuration determines an element's chemical behaviour. Elements react to achieve stable, full outer shells, so knowing how electrons are arranged lets you predict how elements will bond and react.

items.title: I can identify valence electrons from an electron configuration
items.what: Valence electrons are the electrons in the outermost shell of an atom. They are the electrons involved in chemical bonding and reactions.
items.why: Valence electrons determine how an element bonds with others. Elements with the same number of valence electrons have similar chemical properties.
items.example: Chlorine has electron configuration 2,8,7. The 7 in the last position means chlorine has 7 valence electrons.

subtopic.name: Electron Configuration
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how electrons are arranged in shells around the nucleus. You will learn the rules for filling electron shells and how to represent electron arrangements using shell diagrams and electron configuration notation.
subtopic.why: Electron configuration determines an element's chemical behaviour. Elements react to achieve stable, full outer shells, so knowing how electrons are arranged lets you predict how elements will bond and react.

items.title: I can determine an element's group and period from its electron configuration
items.what: The number of occupied shells equals the period number. The number of valence electrons equals the group number (for main group elements).
items.why: This connection explains why the periodic table is arranged as it is and allows you to predict an element's position from its electron structure.
items.example: An element with configuration 2,8,8,1 has 4 occupied shells (Period 4) and 1 valence electron (Group 1). This is potassium.

subtopic.name: Electron Configuration
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how electrons are arranged in shells around the nucleus. You will learn the rules for filling electron shells and how to represent electron arrangements using shell diagrams and electron configuration notation.
subtopic.why: Electron configuration determines an element's chemical behaviour. Elements react to achieve stable, full outer shells, so knowing how electrons are arranged lets you predict how elements will bond and react.

items.title: I can identify groups and periods on the periodic table
items.what: Groups are vertical columns numbered 1-18. Periods are horizontal rows numbered 1-7. Each element has a unique position defined by its group and period.
items.why: Groups and periods organise elements by electron arrangement, making it possible to predict properties from position alone.
items.example: Silicon is in Period 3, Group 14. This means silicon atoms have 3 electron shells and 4 valence electrons.

subtopic.name: Periodic Table Organisation
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how the periodic table is organised into groups (columns) and periods (rows), and how elements are classified as metals, non-metals, or metalloids based on their position and properties.
subtopic.why: Understanding the organisation of the periodic table allows you to predict element properties without memorising individual facts. Position reveals electron arrangement, reactivity, and physical properties.

items.title: I can locate an element on the periodic table given its electron configuration
items.what: Count the number of shells to find the period. Count valence electrons to find the group. This works reliably for main group elements.
items.why: This skill allows you to navigate between electron structure and periodic table position in either direction.
items.example: An atom with electron configuration 2,8,7 has 3 shells (Period 3) and 7 valence electrons (Group 17). This is chlorine.

subtopic.name: Periodic Table Organisation
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how the periodic table is organised into groups (columns) and periods (rows), and how elements are classified as metals, non-metals, or metalloids based on their position and properties.
subtopic.why: Understanding the organisation of the periodic table allows you to predict element properties without memorising individual facts. Position reveals electron arrangement, reactivity, and physical properties.

items.title: I can classify elements as metals, non-metals, or metalloids based on their position
items.what: Metals are on the left and centre of the periodic table. Non-metals are on the right. Metalloids (like silicon and germanium) form a diagonal staircase between them.
items.why: Classification helps predict properties. Metals conduct electricity and are malleable. Non-metals are often brittle and do not conduct. Metalloids have intermediate properties.
items.example: Aluminium (Group 13) is left of the metalloid line, so it is a metal. Sulfur (Group 16) is right of the line, so it is a non-metal.

subtopic.name: Periodic Table Organisation
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how the periodic table is organised into groups (columns) and periods (rows), and how elements are classified as metals, non-metals, or metalloids based on their position and properties.
subtopic.why: Understanding the organisation of the periodic table allows you to predict element properties without memorising individual facts. Position reveals electron arrangement, reactivity, and physical properties.

items.title: I can describe typical properties of metals, non-metals, and metalloids
items.what: Metals are lustrous, malleable, ductile, and conduct electricity. Non-metals are dull, brittle, and do not conduct. Metalloids have mixed properties and can act as semiconductors.
items.why: Knowing typical properties helps you predict how substances will behave and why certain materials are chosen for specific uses.
items.example: Copper is a metal, so it is shiny, can be drawn into wire (ductile), and conducts electricity well, making it ideal for electrical wiring.

subtopic.name: Periodic Table Organisation
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how the periodic table is organised into groups (columns) and periods (rows), and how elements are classified as metals, non-metals, or metalloids based on their position and properties.
subtopic.why: Understanding the organisation of the periodic table allows you to predict element properties without memorising individual facts. Position reveals electron arrangement, reactivity, and physical properties.

items.title: I can identify the names of key groups in the periodic table
items.what: Group 1 are the alkali metals. Group 2 are the alkaline earth metals. Group 17 are the halogens. Group 18 are the noble gases.
items.why: These group names are used frequently in chemistry. Knowing them helps you communicate about element families efficiently.
items.example: When someone says 'halogens are reactive non-metals,' you know they mean fluorine, chlorine, bromine, iodine, and astatine in Group 17.

subtopic.name: Periodic Table Organisation
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how the periodic table is organised into groups (columns) and periods (rows), and how elements are classified as metals, non-metals, or metalloids based on their position and properties.
subtopic.why: Understanding the organisation of the periodic table allows you to predict element properties without memorising individual facts. Position reveals electron arrangement, reactivity, and physical properties.

items.title: I can describe how atomic radius changes across a period and down a group
items.what: Atomic radius decreases across a period (left to right) because more protons pull electrons closer. Atomic radius increases down a group because additional electron shells make atoms larger.
items.why: Atomic size affects many properties including reactivity, melting point, and how easily electrons are lost or gained.
items.example: Sodium atoms are larger than chlorine atoms (same period). Potassium atoms are larger than sodium atoms (same group, lower period).

subtopic.name: Trends in the Periodic Table
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how properties like atomic radius, reactivity, and melting point change systematically across periods and down groups. These patterns result from changes in electron arrangement and nuclear charge.
subtopic.why: Understanding trends allows you to predict properties of elements you have not studied directly. If you know the pattern, you can make reliable predictions about unfamiliar elements.

items.title: I can explain the trend in metal reactivity down Groups 1 and 2
items.what: Metal reactivity increases down Groups 1 and 2. Larger atoms have valence electrons further from the nucleus, making them easier to lose in reactions.
items.why: This explains why caesium reacts explosively with water while lithium reacts gently, even though both are alkali metals.
items.example: Potassium reacts more violently with water than sodium because potassium's valence electron is in the fourth shell, further from the nucleus and easier to lose.

subtopic.name: Trends in the Periodic Table
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how properties like atomic radius, reactivity, and melting point change systematically across periods and down groups. These patterns result from changes in electron arrangement and nuclear charge.
subtopic.why: Understanding trends allows you to predict properties of elements you have not studied directly. If you know the pattern, you can make reliable predictions about unfamiliar elements.

items.title: I can explain the trend in non-metal reactivity down Group 17
items.what: Halogen reactivity decreases down Group 17. Smaller atoms have their outer shell closer to the nucleus, making it easier to attract and gain electrons.
items.why: This explains why fluorine is the most reactive non-metal while iodine is much less reactive.
items.example: Chlorine can displace bromine from potassium bromide solution because chlorine is more reactive. Bromine cannot displace chlorine from potassium chloride.

subtopic.name: Trends in the Periodic Table
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how properties like atomic radius, reactivity, and melting point change systematically across periods and down groups. These patterns result from changes in electron arrangement and nuclear charge.
subtopic.why: Understanding trends allows you to predict properties of elements you have not studied directly. If you know the pattern, you can make reliable predictions about unfamiliar elements.

items.title: I can use melting and boiling point data to predict physical state at room temperature
items.what: If room temperature (25°C) is below the melting point, the substance is solid. If it is between melting and boiling points, it is liquid. If it is above the boiling point, it is gas.
items.why: This skill allows you to interpret data tables and make predictions about how substances will appear under normal conditions.
items.example: Bromine has melting point -7°C and boiling point 59°C. At 25°C, bromine is between these values, so it is a liquid at room temperature.

subtopic.name: Trends in the Periodic Table
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how properties like atomic radius, reactivity, and melting point change systematically across periods and down groups. These patterns result from changes in electron arrangement and nuclear charge.
subtopic.why: Understanding trends allows you to predict properties of elements you have not studied directly. If you know the pattern, you can make reliable predictions about unfamiliar elements.

items.title: I can relate melting point trends to bond strength
items.what: Higher melting points indicate stronger bonding between particles. Metals in Groups 1 and 2 have decreasing melting points down the group as metallic bonding weakens with larger atoms.
items.why: Melting point data provides evidence about the relative strength of bonding in different substances.
items.example: Lithium melts at 181°C while caesium melts at 28°C. This shows metallic bonding is weaker in caesium due to its larger atomic size.

subtopic.name: Trends in the Periodic Table
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how properties like atomic radius, reactivity, and melting point change systematically across periods and down groups. These patterns result from changes in electron arrangement and nuclear charge.
subtopic.why: Understanding trends allows you to predict properties of elements you have not studied directly. If you know the pattern, you can make reliable predictions about unfamiliar elements.

items.title: I can use density data to predict whether a substance will float or sink in water
items.what: Substances with density less than 1.0 g/mL will float in water. Substances with density greater than 1.0 g/mL will sink. Water has a density of exactly 1.0 g/mL.
items.why: Density comparisons are practical for predicting physical behaviour and are often tested using data tables.
items.example: Potassium has a density of 0.86 g/mL, which is less than water (1.0 g/mL), so potassium floats on water before it reacts.

subtopic.name: Trends in the Periodic Table
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how properties like atomic radius, reactivity, and melting point change systematically across periods and down groups. These patterns result from changes in electron arrangement and nuclear charge.
subtopic.why: Understanding trends allows you to predict properties of elements you have not studied directly. If you know the pattern, you can make reliable predictions about unfamiliar elements.

items.title: I can describe the properties and reactions of alkali metals
items.what: Group 1 metals are soft, have low melting points, and react vigorously with water to produce hydrogen gas and a metal hydroxide solution. Reactivity increases down the group.
items.why: Alkali metals demonstrate the trend of increasing metal reactivity down a group and show how having one valence electron leads to predictable behaviour.
items.example: Sodium reacts with water: sodium + water → sodium hydroxide + hydrogen. The reaction produces fizzing (hydrogen gas) and the solution turns phenolphthalein pink (basic).

subtopic.name: Group Properties
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the specific properties and reactions of four important groups: alkali metals (Group 1), alkaline earth metals (Group 2), halogens (Group 17), and noble gases (Group 18).
subtopic.why: These groups demonstrate clear patterns that illustrate periodic trends. Understanding their properties helps you apply general principles to predict behaviour of specific elements.

items.title: I can describe the properties and reactions of alkaline earth metals
items.what: Group 2 metals are harder than Group 1 metals and also react with water, though less vigorously. They have two valence electrons and form 2+ ions.
items.why: Comparing Groups 1 and 2 shows how the number of valence electrons affects reactivity. It takes more energy to remove two electrons than one.
items.example: Magnesium reacts slowly with cold water but vigorously with steam: magnesium + water → magnesium hydroxide + hydrogen.

subtopic.name: Group Properties
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the specific properties and reactions of four important groups: alkali metals (Group 1), alkaline earth metals (Group 2), halogens (Group 17), and noble gases (Group 18).
subtopic.why: These groups demonstrate clear patterns that illustrate periodic trends. Understanding their properties helps you apply general principles to predict behaviour of specific elements.

items.title: I can describe the properties and reactions of halogens
items.what: Group 17 elements are reactive non-metals that exist as diatomic molecules (F₂, Cl₂, Br₂, I₂). They gain one electron to form 1- ions. Reactivity decreases down the group.
items.why: Halogens show the opposite reactivity trend to metals because they gain electrons rather than lose them. Smaller atoms gain electrons more easily.
items.example: Chlorine is a yellow-green gas, bromine is a brown liquid, and iodine is a purple-grey solid at room temperature. All are toxic.

subtopic.name: Group Properties
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the specific properties and reactions of four important groups: alkali metals (Group 1), alkaline earth metals (Group 2), halogens (Group 17), and noble gases (Group 18).
subtopic.why: These groups demonstrate clear patterns that illustrate periodic trends. Understanding their properties helps you apply general principles to predict behaviour of specific elements.

items.title: I can explain why noble gases are unreactive
items.what: Group 18 elements have full outer shells (2 for helium, 8 for others). They do not need to gain or lose electrons to achieve stability, so they rarely react.
items.why: Noble gases represent the stable electron configuration that all other elements are trying to achieve through chemical reactions.
items.example: Neon has electron configuration 2,8 with a full outer shell. It does not react with other elements because it is already stable.

subtopic.name: Group Properties
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the specific properties and reactions of four important groups: alkali metals (Group 1), alkaline earth metals (Group 2), halogens (Group 17), and noble gases (Group 18).
subtopic.why: These groups demonstrate clear patterns that illustrate periodic trends. Understanding their properties helps you apply general principles to predict behaviour of specific elements.

items.title: I can predict displacement reactions between halogens
items.what: A more reactive halogen will displace a less reactive halogen from its compound. Chlorine displaces bromine; bromine displaces iodine; but iodine cannot displace chlorine or bromine.
items.why: Displacement reactions provide evidence for the reactivity series and demonstrate competition for electrons between elements.
items.example: When chlorine water is added to potassium bromide solution, the solution turns orange as chlorine displaces bromine: Cl₂ + 2KBr → 2KCl + Br₂.

subtopic.name: Group Properties
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the specific properties and reactions of four important groups: alkali metals (Group 1), alkaline earth metals (Group 2), halogens (Group 17), and noble gases (Group 18).
subtopic.why: These groups demonstrate clear patterns that illustrate periodic trends. Understanding their properties helps you apply general principles to predict behaviour of specific elements.

items.title: I can write word equations for reactions of metals with water and chlorine
items.what: Metals react with water to produce metal hydroxide and hydrogen gas. Metals react with chlorine to produce metal chloride. These are predictable patterns.
items.why: Being able to write reaction equations demonstrates understanding of what products form and allows you to predict unfamiliar reactions.
items.example: Potassium + water → potassium hydroxide + hydrogen. Potassium + chlorine → potassium chloride.

subtopic.name: Group Properties
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the specific properties and reactions of four important groups: alkali metals (Group 1), alkaline earth metals (Group 2), halogens (Group 17), and noble gases (Group 18).
subtopic.why: These groups demonstrate clear patterns that illustrate periodic trends. Understanding their properties helps you apply general principles to predict behaviour of specific elements.

items.title: I can predict the charge of ions formed by main group elements
items.what: Metals lose electrons to form positive ions (cations). Non-metals gain electrons to form negative ions (anions). The charge equals the number of electrons transferred to achieve a full outer shell.
items.why: Predicting ion charges is essential for writing correct formulas and understanding why compounds have specific ratios of elements.
items.example: Magnesium (Group 2) loses 2 electrons to form Mg²⁺. Chlorine (Group 17) gains 1 electron to form Cl⁻.

subtopic.name: Ionic Bonding
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how metals and non-metals form ionic compounds through electron transfer. You will learn to predict ion charges, draw electron transfer diagrams, and write formulas for ionic compounds.
subtopic.why: Ionic bonding explains how most salts and minerals form. Understanding electron transfer connects atomic structure to compound formation and explains why certain ratios of elements combine.

items.title: I can explain the difference between cations and anions
items.what: Cations are positive ions formed when atoms lose electrons. Anions are negative ions formed when atoms gain electrons. The names come from the electrodes they move toward.
items.why: Distinguishing between cations and anions is fundamental to understanding ionic bonding and electrolysis.
items.example: Sodium atoms lose one electron to become Na⁺ cations. Fluorine atoms gain one electron to become F⁻ anions (called fluoride ions).

subtopic.name: Ionic Bonding
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how metals and non-metals form ionic compounds through electron transfer. You will learn to predict ion charges, draw electron transfer diagrams, and write formulas for ionic compounds.
subtopic.why: Ionic bonding explains how most salts and minerals form. Understanding electron transfer connects atomic structure to compound formation and explains why certain ratios of elements combine.

items.title: I can draw electron shell diagrams showing ionic bond formation
items.what: Draw the atoms, show electrons transferring from metal to non-metal, then show the resulting ions with their charges and electron arrangements matching a noble gas.
items.why: These diagrams provide visual evidence of how ionic bonds form and why specific ions result from specific atoms.
items.example: For NaCl: draw sodium (2,8,1) losing its outer electron to chlorine (2,8,7), resulting in Na⁺ (2,8) and Cl⁻ (2,8,8).

subtopic.name: Ionic Bonding
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how metals and non-metals form ionic compounds through electron transfer. You will learn to predict ion charges, draw electron transfer diagrams, and write formulas for ionic compounds.
subtopic.why: Ionic bonding explains how most salts and minerals form. Understanding electron transfer connects atomic structure to compound formation and explains why certain ratios of elements combine.

items.title: I can identify which noble gas an ion has the same electron configuration as
items.what: After forming ions, elements have the same number of electrons as a noble gas. This stable configuration is why atoms form ions in the first place.
items.why: Recognising noble gas configurations reinforces why specific charges form and connects ion formation to stability.
items.example: Na⁺ has 10 electrons (2,8), the same as neon. Cl⁻ has 18 electrons (2,8,8), the same as argon.

subtopic.name: Ionic Bonding
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how metals and non-metals form ionic compounds through electron transfer. You will learn to predict ion charges, draw electron transfer diagrams, and write formulas for ionic compounds.
subtopic.why: Ionic bonding explains how most salts and minerals form. Understanding electron transfer connects atomic structure to compound formation and explains why certain ratios of elements combine.

items.title: I can write formulas for ionic compounds using the crossover method
items.what: Write the ions with their charges. Cross over the charge numbers to become subscripts on the opposite ion. Simplify if needed. The compound must be electrically neutral.
items.why: Writing correct formulas is essential for describing compounds precisely and for balancing equations.
items.example: For magnesium chloride: Mg²⁺ and Cl⁻. Cross over: Mg₁Cl₂. The formula is MgCl₂ (one magnesium ion for every two chloride ions).

subtopic.name: Ionic Bonding
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how metals and non-metals form ionic compounds through electron transfer. You will learn to predict ion charges, draw electron transfer diagrams, and write formulas for ionic compounds.
subtopic.why: Ionic bonding explains how most salts and minerals form. Understanding electron transfer connects atomic structure to compound formation and explains why certain ratios of elements combine.

items.title: I can explain why ionic compounds have high melting points
items.what: Ionic compounds contain strong electrostatic attractions between oppositely charged ions throughout the lattice. A lot of energy is needed to overcome these attractions.
items.why: Melting point relates directly to bond strength. High melting points of ionic compounds are evidence of strong ionic bonding.
items.example: Sodium chloride melts at 801°C because the Na⁺ and Cl⁻ ions are held together by strong electrostatic forces that require significant energy to break.

subtopic.name: Ionic Bonding
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how metals and non-metals form ionic compounds through electron transfer. You will learn to predict ion charges, draw electron transfer diagrams, and write formulas for ionic compounds.
subtopic.why: Ionic bonding explains how most salts and minerals form. Understanding electron transfer connects atomic structure to compound formation and explains why certain ratios of elements combine.

items.title: I can explain why ionic compounds conduct electricity when molten or dissolved
items.what: Ionic compounds conduct electricity only when their ions are free to move. This occurs when the compound is melted or dissolved in water. Solid ionic compounds do not conduct.
items.why: Conductivity tests help identify ionic compounds and demonstrate that moving charged particles are required for electrical conduction.
items.example: Solid NaCl does not conduct electricity because ions are fixed in the lattice. Molten NaCl conducts because Na⁺ and Cl⁻ ions can move freely.
